projects.name: SuperTracker
projects.description:
SuperTracker was an online tool offered by USDA (2011-2018) that helped users track diet, physical activity and weight. SuperTracker provided a personalized plan based on the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans for what you should eat and drink and guided users to making better choices.  This dataset includes the SuperTracker source code (latest update April 2018), including: front end application, database schema, documentation, deployment scripts and a ReadMe.txt file that provides high level instructions for the source code. Database connection strings and actual data are not included. The full foods database spreadsheet is attached as well; these foods are based on the Food and Nutrient Database for Dietary Studies (FNDDS), and the Food Patterns Equivalents Database (FPED), both from the USDA/ARS Food Surveys Research Group.

It is important to note that the code is based on 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans and will not be updated to reflect future guidance. In addition, the food database is based on FNDDS from 2011-2012 (FNDDS 6.0) and FPED from 2011-2012 and will not be updated with future data releases.

projects.name: Fast and robust curve skeletonization for real-world elongated objects

projects.name: Automated Water Supply Model (AWSM)
projects.description: Automated Water Supply Model (AWSM) was developed at the USDA Agricultural Research Service (ARS) in Boise, ID. AWSM was designed to streamline the work flow used by the ARS to forecast the water supply of multiple water basins. AWSM standardizes the steps needed to distribute weather station data with SMRF, run an energy and mass balance with iSnobal, and process the results, while maintaining the flexibility of each program.

projects.name: Spatial Modeling for Resources Framework (SMRF)
projects.description: Spatial Modeling for Resources Framework (SMRF) was developed by Dr. Scott Havens at the USDA Agricultural Research Service (ARS) in Boise, ID. SMRF was designed to increase the flexibility of taking measured weather data and distributing the point measurements across a watershed. SMRF was developed to be used as an operational or research framework, where ease of use, efficiency, and ability to run in near real time are high priorities.

projects.name: Weather Database
projects.description: The Weather Database project creates a MySQL database to ingest and manage weather station data from multiple sources. Included in the repository are the schema model and everything needed to generate a weather station database. The wxdb package is able to interact with the database and grab metadata and station data from multiple sources.

projects.description: The basin setup tool is a python script designed to create the required inputs for running SMRF and AWSM simulations. The tool outputs a single netcdf file containing the necessary spatial information for a water basin This includes basin mask, DEM, veg type and height (from Landfire), veg tau, and veg K.

agencyName: Department of Housing and Urban Development

projects.name: Geocoding Service Center
projects.description: The Geocoding Service Center (GSC) is an enterprise tool providing address validation, standarization, and geocoding for 17 HUD systems. The GSC is a data repository for geographic information (USPS delivery point and ZIP9 data; Census data such as counties, localities, census tract, census block; MSA/CBSA; Longitude and latitude)  The GSC provides geographic information that can be used with mapping software to map locations such as HUD owned properties, underserved areas or national disaster areas.

projects.name: Loan Accounting System
projects.description: LAS, a mixed financial system, performs the direct loan servicing activities required to support the Department's Section 202 Supportive Housing for the Elderly Program, Section 201 Flexible Subsidy Program, Section 236 Excess Rental Income Program, the Green Retrofit Program and the Emergency Home Loan Program. The system maintains the loan amortization schedules, generates the monthly interest amounts due and principal amounts due, and applies collections to the interest and principal amounts due and all excess amounts are recorded in the project/loan suspense account.

projects.name: HUD Procurement System
projects.description: The HUD Procurement System (HPS) automates the contract procurement and acquisition process by recording, monitoring and reporting the status of all Actions throughout the procurement lifecycle.

projects.name: HUD's Consolidated Financial Statement System
projects.description: HCFSS, a mixed financial system, performs consolidation and analysis of cumulative data from HUD Central Accounting and Program System (HUDCAPS) on a monthly basis. Quarterly, HCFSS is used to generate HUDâ€™s Governmentwide Treasury Account Symbol Adjusted Trial Balance System (GTAS) reports for submission to the Department of Treasury..

projects.name: Single Family Insurance System
projects.description: The Single Family Insurance System (SFIS) is the FHA repository of Single Family insured mortgages. SFIS is the system of record for all FHA insured Single Family loans and case records. There is one record for every active Single Family case and one record for each terminated case since 1984. Since October of 1983, Single Family Insurance System (SFIS) has been used to maintain the insurance-in-force (IIF) database, which contains accurate and detailed case information on FHA-insured single family properties.

projects.name: Single Family Insurance System-Claims Subsystem
projects.description: The Single Family Insurance Claim System provides on-line update and inquiry capability to Single Family Insurance and Claims data bases and to cumulative history files. .

projects.name: Telephone Directory and Locator System
projects.description: This system provides for the immediate update and retrieval of names, locations, organizations, and phone numbers of all personnel assigned to HUD headquarters. It is used to assist the locator personnel in responding to HUD directory assistance calls and to produce the HUD phone directory.

projects.name: Line of Credit Control System
projects.description: LOCCS, a mixed financial system, is a disbursement and cash management system that services 86 HUD Program Areas, 17,679 grantees, and controls payments for over 480,000 projects.

projects.name: Inventory of Automated Systems
projects.description: The Inventory of Automated Systems (IAS) keeps an inventory of the automated applications (or systems) which support business areas within the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD).

projects.name: HUD Central Accounting and Program System
projects.description: HUDCAPS is no longer the Departmentâ€™s core financial system/system of record due to implementation of New Core Project Phase 1 Release 3. HUDCAPS now serves as a sub-ledger financial system and Oracle Federal Financials serves as the Departmentâ€™s system of record and core financial system. The following types of transactions were migrated to Oracle Federal Financials: â€¢Budget transactions (e.g., appropriation, apportionment, allotment, sub-allotment, and realignment) associated with all funds.

projects.name: Personal Svcs Cost Rpt Subsystem
projects.description: Personal Service Cost Report Subsystem (PSCRS) is used to support HUD's interfaces with the payroll system and acts as a batch processor/translator for HUD. PSCRS is a subsystem of HUD Central Accounting and Program System (HUDCAPS), the Department's general ledger.

projects.name: Financial Data Mart
projects.description: FDM, a mixed financial system, is a warehouse of data extracted from a variety of the Department's financial systems and supported by a number of query tools for the purpose of improved financial and program data reporting. FDM is the primary reporting tool used to generate internal adâ€“hoc reports, scheduled event driven reports, and queries.

projects.name: Single Family Premium Collection Subsystem-Periodic
projects.description: The Single Family Premiums Collection Subsystem - Periodic provides case-level reconciliation, premium billing, collection, reconciliation, refunding and accounting processes for the Single Family Insurance Operations Division of the Office of Financial Services. The system was implemented in September, 1999 as a replacement for A31/SFPC and incorporated the reconciliation functions performed by the contractor MGIC Independent Services. The system calculates monthly premiums due for the risk-based cases in the SFIS (A43) system, prepares monthly bills, reconciles and accounts for payments received, and provides data for monitoring lender performance.

projects.name: Distributive Shares and Refund Subsystem
projects.description: The Distributive Shares and Refund Subsystem (DSRS) was implemented in 1991 and replaced the F26 UNISYS system. It was designed in response to a Congressional mandate, in which a new method of collecting insurance premiums was established. Under this new method, a one-time mortgage insurance premium (OTMIP) is paid by the homeowner at closing to cover the life of the loan.

projects.name: Single Family Premiums Collection Subsystem - Upfront
projects.description: The SFPCS-U is an ongoing, fully operational financial system that supports HUDâ€™s Single Family Insurance Operations Division (SFIOD). The A80R/SFPCS-U replaced the One-Time Mortgage Insurance Premium System. The system is tasked with the collection, reconciliation, and accounting of upfront mortgage insurance premiums (MIP) for FHA insured home loans. Insurance premiums are collected from borrowers at closing by mortgage lenders. A80R/SFPCS-U automates the collection of upfront mortgage insurance premiums from mortgage lenders through electronic funds transfer facilitated by the Treasury Department's Pay.Gov facility.

projects.name: Single Family Acquired Asset Management System
projects.description: The purpose of SAMS is to record all data associated with the daily maintenence of case records. It tracks movements of properties from acquisition to final sales closing using various data screens to move cases to steps. The system maintains all accounting data associated with the case records in accordance with the requirements of the Director, General Accounting Office (GAO), Department of the Treasury, Office of Manangement and Budget (OMB) and Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). SAMS is Year 2000 compliant in the storing and retrieving of data.

projects.name: Single Family Neighborhood Watch
projects.description: Single Family Neighborhood Watch (SFNW/A80W) was developed in response to Single Family Housingâ€™s need for an analytical tool to aid the Department in monitoring FHA-approved lenders, HUD programs and loan performance by geographic area. SFNW also aids lenders and the public in self-policing the industry. As of November 13, 2013, there are 21,058 registered users plus the general public. Neighborhood Watch is a web browser-based risk assessment/decision support tool which identifies lenders, loan types, and locations by geographic areas that have high incidence of single family insured mortgages 30, 60 and 90 days delinquent within the first or second year from loan origination.

projects.name: Program Accounting System
projects.description: Program Accounting System (PAS) provides fund accountability and an integrated subsidiary for the Department's grant, subsidy, and loan programs. PAS maintains accounting records based on Commitment, Obligation, and Payment activity for HUD funding programs. PAS controls new program funds for Treasury Appropriation Accounts.

projects.name: Integrated Disbursement & Information System
projects.description: IDIS OnLine is a web-based grants management system used by CPD to automate administration of formula grants including CDBG, HOME, HOPWA, and ESG. IDIS also supports special grants established by the 2009 American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) including TCAP, CDBG-R, and HPRP.

projects.name: HUD Environmental Review Online System
projects.description: The HUD Environmental Review Online System (HEROS) is a web-based module in HUDâ€™s Integrated Disbursement & Information System (IDIS). HEROS computerizes the environmental review process and increases accountability and transparency for projects receiving HUD assistance. HEROS sends Environmental Review documents to OneCPD Resource Exchange website for accessibility by all parties.

projects.name: CPD Grants Management Process
projects.description: The Grants Management Process initiative provides support to the Departmentâ€™s mission to help the nationâ€™s communities meet their development needs; spur economic growth in distressed neighborhoods; provide housing assistance for the poor; help rehabilitate and develop moderate and low-cost housing, and enforce the nationâ€™s fair housing laws. CPD is responsible for more than 20 programs, distributing close to $8 billion annually and manages more than 1,000 formula and competitive grantees across the nation.

projects.name: Disaster Recovery Grant Reporting
projects.description: DRGR is a web-based grants management application providing real-time financial disbursement, tracking, and reporting activities for HUDâ€™s disaster grant programs. DRGR enables grantees to establish strategic plans, citizen participation plans, and action plans; draw program funds; and report on the activities, beneficiaries, properties, matching funds, and other accomplishment data. DRGR provides timely performance information regarding accomplishments achieved with use of program funds, pursuant to the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993 (GPRA) and program regulations.

projects.name: Electronic Special Needs Assistance Program System
projects.description: The COC Homeless Assistance program was enacted by the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act (P.L. 100-77) of July 1987. e-snaps directly supports HUD's mission to decrease homelessness in America by improving how CPD staff manage the following CoC McKinney grant programs: 1) Subtitle C of Title IV Supportive Housing Programs (SHP), 24 CFR part 583; 2) Subtitle F of Title IV Shelter Plus Care (S+C), 24 CFR part 582; 3) Section 441, Single Room Occupancy (SRO), 24 CFR part 882. In May 2009, President Obama signed the Homeless Emergency Assistance and Rapid Transition to Housing (HEARTH) Act.

projects.name: TitleV / BRAC
projects.description: New Re-engineered TitleV 5.0 is a web-based J2EE application using Oracle database server as backend. The J2EE application server is Sun One Application Server 8.1.  The new TitleV 5.0 continues to track the surplus Federal properties as ordered by the Federal Court.  Title V 5.0 still contains property information on the properties reported to HUD by all Federal land holding agencies and is the vehicle for establishing the properties in the Federal Register.

projects.name: Empowerment Zones/Renewal Communities Performance Measurement System
projects.description: The need for a CPD Empowerment Zones/Renewal Communities systems (EZ/RC PERMS - C39) is based on work in partnership with States, regions, and localities to reduce unnecessary Federal paperwork, simplify Federal requirements, and reduce administrative burdens by consolidating and simplifying planning, application, and reporting requirements for EZ/RC awarded communities.

projects.name: Administrative Client Request/Response System
projects.description: The Administrative Client Request/Response System is an Office of Administrative and Management Services sponsored system that enables a HUD employee to request Administrative services from their desktop computer and have the request routed directly to the service provider.

projects.name: Administrative National Services Supplies Request System
projects.description: This system automates business processes used by HUD personnel to acquire the needed goods and services & to manage the tasks resulting from such requests. ANSRS supports HUD's internal customers allowing them to initiate electronic requests for services.

projects.name: OHR Office of Personnel & Training Inquiry System
projects.description: The purpose of this system is to provide the Office of Human Resources with personnel action information and updates which are provided by the National Financial Center's Payroll/Personnel System. It maintains SF-50 personnel data in perpetuity. The system records personnel actions which are used to produce EEO reports to meet the requirements of several Federal regulations.

projects.name: Direct Distribution System SpectrumPlus
projects.description: The Direct Distribution System SpectrumPlus DDS S+ is a Commercial-off-the-Shelf (COTS) package. The DDS S+ gives HUD employees, clients, and stakeholders the capability to request printed copies of documents and/or forms via the telephone, fax, or Internet. The system is used to distribute guidebooks, handbooks, forms, and literature to citizens, industry, employees, public housing authorities, and Governments that are required to comply with HUD regulations.  The Direct Distribution System powers the distribution center. The technology is used to enter orders, manage inventory, produce requisition tickets for pre-printed documents, and to print-on-demand (POD) documents that are digitized and produced when they are needed. DDS supports two units?the Customer Service Center (CSC) and the Fulfillment Center.

projects.name: OCFO WebFocus CAP Reports System
projects.description: A reporting tool that extracts data from multiple databases across multiple platforms to generate reports for the Program Areas and the OCFO Office of Budget. WebFocus environment allows the Program Areas and Office of Budget staff to use canned reports or produce their own reports by providing simple parameters already established using user-friendly screens. Data for the CAP reports is downloaded to the system biweekly through the Consolidated Cost & FTE Files (A91) Unisys mainframe. The WebFocus CAP reports are generated after the creation of consolidated files through the A91 system. The CAP reporting tool allows any valid user the ability to track personal services expenditures and FTE utilization.

projects.name: HUD Client Information and Policy System
projects.description: This system will provide HUD clients and staff with electronic access to the Department's regulations, policy directives, and procedures. The system will provide three levels of service as follows: Level I - The electronic distribution of new HUD documents. Level II - The full text search and retrieval capabilities of HUD directives. This level will replace the current Directives Ã¬Access System (DAS, D12). Level III - The capability for graphic search and retrieval. This will be integrated with all the capabilities of Level II. The services are currently provided by Drayton,Drayton & Lemar Inc., who provides HUDCLIPS as a service to HUD, HUD clients, and the general public. HUDCLIPS is sponsored by OAMS.

projects.name: HUD Communication Manager
projects.description: HCM allows for the quick generation and distribution of letters, labels, faxes, and reports from a customizable database. It uses RightFax for mass faxing. The name of the system was changed from ICS to HCM in 1999.

projects.name: Equal Employment Opportunity Management Information System
projects.description: The EEOMIS system is a web based system.

projects.name: EZBudget Formulation System
projects.description: EZBudget Formulation System (EZB) provides a streamlined and systematic approach to budget formulation for individual HUD Programs, HUD Salaries and Expenses and Jointly Administered Programs. It allows HUD to centralize, search, classify, control, and track information, and to simplify the budgetary development process. EZB provides a single source of budgetary information to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and budget data for justifications to Congress.

projects.name: Single Family Housing Enterprise Data Warehouse
projects.description: The D64A SFHEDW data warehouse resides on a virtual UNIX Server and uses Sybase IQ 15.2 as the primary Data Base Management System (DBMS) and Sybase ASE as a secondary DBMS for metadata. Some Source data from the legacy systems is edited and merged on the IBM mainframe server and formatted into files and loaded into the Unix Server. Many files are transferred by the source syard (FRB) 5. F51 - Institution Master File (IMF) - system replaced by data feed from P278 (LEAP) SFHEDW/D64A provides data to the following applications/entities: 1. A80W - Single Family Neighborhood Watch (SFNW) 2. A15 - Geocoding Service Center (GSC) 3. P013 - FHA Subsidiary Ledger (FHA-SL) 4. F17 - Computerized Homes Underwriting Management System (CHUMS). 5. P260 - Asset Disposition And Management System (ADAMS) - a.k.a. "Yardi" 6. A43 â€“ Single Family Insurance System (SFIS) 7. P202 - Policy and Research Information Center (PARIS) 8. N/A - External - Loan Performance (Core Logic) data extracts 9. N/A - External - Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) The following data marts and special tables are maintained in SFHEDW/D64A: 1. Appraiser Review System (ARS) 2. Claims 3. Defaults 4. Default Summary 5. Loan Limits 6. Generic Debt Management System (GDEBT) 7. Ginnie Mae (GNMA)(RESTRICTED ACCESS) 8. HUDStat 9. Home Equity Conversion Mortgage (HECM) 10. Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) 11. Hope for Homeowners (H4H) 12. Integrated Database (IDB) 13. Loss Mitigation Portfolio Analysis (LMPA) 14. Natural disaster [formerly Hurricane Effort (2005)] 15. Public (reference tables) 16. Single Family Assets 17. Single Family Premium Collection System (SFPCS) 18. Single Family Real Estate Owned (REO) [formerly Property Disposition(SAMS)] 19. Title I 20. Special tables for Credit Scoring analysis (RESTRICTED ACCESS) 21. Metadata 22. Underwriting Reporting System (URS) In addition to the data marts listed above, there are the miscellaneous tables created for groups and/or offices like the OIG in Los Angeles and PD&R. A moving set of tables based on fiscal year data is also maintained to support the FHA Audit.

projects.name: Facilities Asset Management Enterprise System
projects.description: Proven web based asset management system, FAMES is a web based system that fully supports the Government property management business practices as defined by Government regulations and policies. It allows for optimal tracking and inventorying of agency wide personal property at HUD with the help of a mobile handheld scanner. FAMES also automate the reuse or disposal of assets. FAMES was designed as an enterprise system in order to help ensure success and reduce costs, HUD can leverage FAMES to interface with HUD General Ledger, the acquisition system PRISM, and with HIHRTS as source of data. Other HUD systems such as NEW CORE, ABS, and CHAMPS will need to be interfaced to automate HUD business process within FAMES. Note: This is an Azure cloud-based.

projects.name: HATS/PERIS NFC FTP
projects.description: Collects data from the National Finance Center. The data is used by several applications.

projects.name: HUD Enterprise Geographic Information System
projects.description: This system has 3 separate environments: development, test, and production. Each environment is identical from a hardware and software standpoint, comprising of one Windows web/application server and one Unix database server, for a total of 6 physical (not virtual) servers in all. The ESRI ArcGIS Server software is installed on the web/app tier along with IIS. The database tier houses an Oracle 11g database and ESRI ArcSDE software. Operation of the ArcGIS Server and geodatabase is currently maintained by staff in the Office of Policy Development and Research with assistance from HITS. The geodatabase is organized into different Oracle schemas, which are based on HUD program office or data theme. The user accounts that own these schemas are used by the geodatabase administrator to load and manage data. Applications that are built on the ArcGIS Server utilize a read only account to access the geodatabase.

projects.name: HUD Empowerment Zone/Renewal Community Locator
projects.description: The Empowerment Zone/Renewal Community Locator (EZ/RC Locator) is a web-based, Geographic Information System (GIS) application that helps businesses certify tax incentive eligibility within Empowerment Zones and Rural Community (EZ/RC) programs.

projects.name: Single Family GIS
projects.description: The Single Family Asset Management GIS System will be a customized implementation of a suite of COTS GIS applications. The primary COTS applications are ArcGIS Server and ArcSDE which already exist within the HUD enterprise architecture, these will be used for map creation and management. For address location, the Single Family Asset Management GIS System will use web software and a geocoder to capture an address and send the results to the application software. All other data will be stored in an Oracle database accessed by the application software. The Single Family Asset Management GIS System will then display a map of the selected area showing the user specified criteria, such as the REO properties and Revitalization Areas within a certain zip code.

projects.name: HUD GIS Maps
projects.description: The tool consists of five separate areas. Click on the appropriate button to access the map and details for any of the following purposesthat map: 1. Disaster Planning - This provides information regarding the potential impact of a disaster on HUDâ€™s physical assets. 2. Public and Indian Housing - This provides information regarding public housing units. 3. Multifamily Project Evaluation - This provides information on multifamily units across the US.

projects.name: CPD Maps
projects.description: CPD Maps (D77D) is a major application that supports analysts in the HUD Office of Community Planning and Development (CPD), as well as the Internal Revenue Service, State and Local governments and the general public. Its main objective is to provide users, including federal, state and local agencies and the general public, with a geographical view of HUD program and community data, U.S. Census Bureau (2010) data, and American Community Survey (ACS) data.

projects.name: Tribal Directory Assessment Tool
projects.description: This system has 3 separate environments: development, test, and production. Each environment is identical from a hardware and software standpoint, comprising of one Windows web/application server and one Unix database server, for a total of 6 physical (not virtual) servers in all.

projects.name: Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing Data and Mapping Tool
projects.description: The AFFHT is a sub-system of the Enterprise GIS Platform (eGIS). The eGIS is comprised of 3 separate environments: development, test, and production. Each environment is identical from a hardware and software standpoint, comprising of one Windows web/application server and one Unix database server, for a total of 6 virtual servers in all.

projects.name: HUD Resource Locator
projects.description: HRL is a sub-system of the Enterprise GIS Platform (eGIS). The eGIS is comprised of 3 separate environments: development, test, and production. Each environment is identical from a hardware and software standpoint, comprising of one Windows web/application server and one Unix database server, for a total of 6 virtual servers in all.

projects.name: HUD Preservation Mapping Tool
projects.description: PMT is a sub-system of the Enterprise GIS Platform (eGIS). The eGIS is comprised of 3 separate environments: development, test, and production.

projects.name: HUD Community Assessment Reporting Tool
projects.description: CART is a sub-system of the Enterprise GIS Platform (eGIS). The eGIS is comprised of 3 separate environments: development, test, and production.

projects.name: Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing User Interface Tool
projects.description: HUD AFFH User Interface application is being developed as a Azure cloud-based secure application using Microsoft ASP.NET, SQL Server, and GIT tools. It is being made available to the HUD external and internal users via HUD Secure Systems (WASS) Portal. It also interfaces with the ESRI mapping service to allow HUD business partners to view fair housing related mapping data to help in completion of their AFH submissions.

projects.name: eGIS Integrated Geodatabase and Map Services
projects.description: This system has 3 separate environments: development, test, and production. Each environment is identical from a hardware and software standpoint, comprising of one Windows web/application server and one Unix database server, for a total of 6 physical (not virtual) servers in all.

projects.name: HUD Application Release Tracking System
projects.description: Some of the major features of the HARTS application are: - Tracks a request from submission through deployment with audit information - Ability to resubmit a request - New closeout feature records if a deployment was successful - Reports can be exported to Excel

projects.name: Electronic Capital Planning Investment Control
projects.description: eCPIC is the information Technology Investment Portfolio System, an innovative web-based Government-Off-The-Shelf (GOTS) decision support and project management application for managing information technology investments, as required by the Clinger Cohen Act of 1996 and OMB circular No. A-11; a tool that is used in conjunction with the Office of IT Reform's existing IT Capital Planning and Investment Process to strengthen and enhance the selection and management of IT projects.

projects.name: Total Maintenance Management System
projects.description: Total Maintenance Management System automates work orders, schedules preventive system aintenance, manages inventory and purchasing, and tracks equipment costs, labor usage, availability, and to meet contractural obligations.

projects.name: Total Estimation & Allocation Mechanism - Resource Estimation & Allocation Process (TEAM-REAP)
projects.description: Total Estimation and Allocation Mechanism (TEAM) captures workload accomplishments and time usage by HUD employees in support of Resource Estimation and Allocation Process (REAP) studies, HUDâ€™s resource management process. The system was developed to link resources to results in compliance with Government Performance & Results Act (GPRA).

projects.name: Section 3 Performance Evaluation and Assessment Reporting System
projects.description: The SPEARS solution contains the following major components: This is the main application used by Authenticated users to submit the Section 60002 Form. It will contain the user interface (view) and application navigation. â€¢SPEARS Business Registry Authenticated Application â€“ This will allow HUD administrators to perform a variety of maintenance and auditing functions. â€¢SPEARS Business Registry Public Application â€“ SPEARS has a component that is accessible to the general public without any authentication, allowing users to register and search for Section 3 Businesses.

projects.name: Housing Counseling System
projects.description: The Housing Counseling System (HCS) is an automated web-based system to support HUDâ€™s Single Family Housing Counseling Program. HCS has several components to collect data for reports and analysis. Three primary components are Agency information, HUD-9902 Report collection, and Grant Processing. The electronic form HUD-9902, Housing Counseling Agency Fiscal Year Activity Report, is available from the HUD web site for agencies to file their reports at the end of each fiscal year. HUD-approved housing counseling agencies, funded state housing finance agencies, and national and regional intermediaries and their funded affiliates are required to submit quarterly and annual HUD-9902 reports on their counseling activities. The 9902 component collects individual and aggregate HUD-9902 reports. HCS provides tools to track agency 9902 submissions and analysis of the data submitted. HUD users can request, by Homeownership Center or HUD-wide, a list of agencies that have reported, a list of those that have not reported, or cumulative totals of data.

projects.name: Agency Reporting Module
projects.description: ARM is a flexible and highly scalable data processing system based on Web Services technology Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP). There are three major components to the ARM processing: the client side which is managed and performed independently by the client deployed at the CMS system; authentication at the enterprise architecture level; and the server side which is the actual â€œcoreâ€ of the ARM processing and web service processing.

projects.name: Computerized Homes Underwriting Management System
projects.description: This system assists and supports Field staff in the processing of single family mortgage insurance applications, from initial receipt through endorsement. Various types of applications are processed in CHUMS, including loans for First Time Homebuyers, Home Equity Conversion Mortgages (HECM) a reverse mortgage available to the elderly to augment income, substantial rehabilitation of existing properties, and VA Certified FHA loans. In addition to tracking and processing assistance, it provides automated assistance in appraisal and mortgage credit evaluation.

projects.name: FHA Connection
projects.description: The FHA Connection is an interactive system available through the Internet that gives approved FHA lenders real-time access to FHA systems for the purpose of conducting official FHA business in an electronic fashion. The FHA Connection is the Internet-based application used by FHA business partners to conduct official business with FHA. Applications available through the FHA Connection include Single Family underwriting, default reporting, portfolio management and others FHA programs.  As of April 1, 2008, 59,342 users from 22,425 institutions and branches have signed up to use the FHA Connection and average volume between 200,000 and 250,000 transactions per day. Updates to FHA Connection are explained and illustrated in the Latest Release Notes (Changes and Processing Instructions (CPIs)). The web page at http://hudatwork.hud.gov/po/h/hs/sys/chums/chumsf17.cfm

projects.name: Integrated Real Estate Management System
projects.description: The Integrated Real Estate Management System (iREMS) is a browser-based application, written in JAVA, and uses a J2EE-based client application connecting to an Oracle database management system. The database and application are maintained and executed on HUDâ€™s Intranet Web Server/Application Server environment. Until all of the legacy applications scheduled to be integrated are rewritten to use the Oracle database, the legacy Housing Enterprise Real Estate Management System (HEREMS) Sybase database will be maintained as the integrated database of record.

projects.name: Development Application Processing System
projects.description: The DAP System provides the Office of Multifamily Housing the ability to administer multifamily housing programs throughout the various phases of construction and the review of processing for both the FHA insurance programs and section 202 (housing for elderly households) and 811 programs (housing for the disabled) application submissions.

projects.name: Mark-To-Market
projects.description: The purpose of the Mark-To-Market program is to test approaches that retain the critical affordable housing resource represented by the supply of 800,000 units of FHA-insured Section 8 assisted housing. It is HUD's objective to maintain this stock in good physical and financial condition, while at the same time reducing the cost of the ongoing Federal subsidy. The Mark-To-Market application supports the Mark-To-Market program by providing the following functionality: 1. A tracking module that captures basic information on the property and where it is in the restructuring process. 2. A financial model that tracks underwriting analysis and scenario information and calculates the anticipated outcome of the restructuring process. 3. A means to track third parties (i.e., Joint Venture Partners and Housing Finance Agencies) working with HUD to restructure the subsidy deal. 4. Various reports.

projects.name: HEREMS Field Office Reporting Utility
projects.description: The HEREMS Field Office Reporting Utility is a MS Access application that uses data downloaded from the Real Estate Management System (REMS)to produce reports for tracking and monitoring properties and Contract Administrators

projects.name: Active Partners Performance System
projects.description: The APPS is designed to support the Departmental business functions covered by the management plan for the re-engineered HUD-2020. The system serves as a replacement for the current Previous Participation Review System (PPRS-F19). It is a state-of-the-art computer automated process designed with a single web-based integrated database, retrievable/changeable via Internet/Intranet. The database contains industry characteristic and business data submitted on form HUD-2530 by industry participants, via the Internet, for Certification to participate in HUD's multifamily housing program project activity (includes data of previous participation wih HUD and other Federal Government Agencies). The APPS automated functionality also includes the Intranet HUD staff's review and approval process of the form HUD-2530 submissions.

projects.name: Consolidated Single Family Statistical System
projects.description: CSFSS/F42 system is required to supply CSFSS statistical information in several formats based on criteria on a daily basis. This system will support efforts to define detailed CSFSS data types and create the required data sets to meet statistical reporting for customer needs. This data is requested year around by various agencies and private sector. But the primary function is to provide statistical data for HUD Headsquarters proram staff for disission making functions.

projects.name: Single Family Default Monitoring Subsystem
projects.description: The Single Family Default Monitoring System is a subsystem of F42. When a mortgage is 90 or more days delinquent, the Mortgagee or Servicer must submit a Single Family Form 92068-a to HUD on a monthly basis until its status has been completed by all Mortgagees and/or is terminated or deleted. Mortgagees and Servicers provide default data via Electronic Data Interchange (EDI) or using the WEB via FHA connection to HUD where they are sorted, pre-screened, key entered, edited, processed and reports are generated for HUD Headquarters and Field Offices review.

projects.name: Institution Master File
projects.description: The Institution Master File (IMF) formerly maintained the official record of institutions (Title I lenders and Title II mortgagees) that are approved by HUD/FHA to originate, service or invest in FHA insured mortgages or loans. IMF centralized institution data needed for the operation of FHAâ€™s home mortgage, project mortgage and home improvement loan insurance programs.

projects.name: Approval & Recertification Tracking System
projects.description: ARRTS is the primary workload management system for Office of Lender Activities and Program Compliance (OLAPC) staff at Headquarters and Quality Assurance Division staff in the four Home Ownership Centers (HOCs). The system provides for a centralized point of access for users to document each stage in the approval and re-authorization process for lenders applying for or renewing their authorization to participate in FHA's programs as well as each step taken to identify and remedy FHA program violations. Use of a single platform for managing workflow between Headquarters and the HOCs and across the three divisions in OLAPC provides for uniformity in data collection on all aspects of work performed and a critical framework for identifying, prioritizing and mitigating risk from 3,600 FHA-approved Lenders.

projects.name: Quality Assurance Document Library System
projects.description: The Quality Assurance Document Library System (QDLS) is a web-based document repository used by the Quality Assurance Division (QAD) at HUD Headquarters and its counterparts in the four Home Ownership Centers (HOCs). The application serves as a central location for QAD staff across the country to store final imaged documents generated as a result of compliance monitoring reviews, OIG audits, and referrals. The application also serves as a resource for QAD staff to access internal reference guides and policies, as well as the standard templates used for conducting monitoring reviews, and generating correspondence.

projects.name: Credit Alert Verification Reporting System
projects.description: The F57/CAIVRS application resides on multiple platforms: The user interface is on the Internet GSS and the databases are on the UNISYS mainframe GSS. CAIVRS database resides on a Unisys/Dorado mainframe server and includes COBOL programs, TIP Screens, DMS 1100 and RDMS 1100 databases. (Note that the TIP screens are no longer used.) The CAIVRS web interface is part of HUDâ€™s F17C/FHA Connection, which is an Internet-based application.   Originally, CAIVRS automated screening was done only through a touch-tone telephone system using a succession of voice response units (VRUs). CAIVRS was created in 1988 for the Office of Housing to check the credit worthiness of applicants for FHA insured loans. Title 31, United States Code, Section 3720B bars â€œdelinquent Federal debtors from obtaining Federal loans or loan insurance guarantees.â€ In 1989, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) mandated that all Federal Credit agencies prescreen all applicants for non-delinquency in Federal debt, through a system of shared data, where practical. In 1990, CAIVRS expanded to include delinquent Federal borrower data from agencies other than HUD, including; USDA, VA, SBA, FDIC, and the Departments of Education and Justice.  HUD receives data and has Computer Matching agreements and Interagency Agreements with the following Federal Agencies: 1. USDA - United States Department of Agriculture a. RURAL HOUSING b. FARM SERVICES 2. SBA - Small Business Administration, 3. VA - Veterans Administration, 4. DOED - Department of Education, a. Guaranteed B. CAIVRS/F57 receives data from the following Single Family legacy systems and other HUD organizations. 1. A43C Single Family Insurance Claims System (CLAIMS) 2. F42D Single Family Default Monitoring System (SFDMS) 3. P278 Lender Electronic Assessment Portal (LEAP-IM)-[replaced F51/IMF - May 2014] 4. F71 Debt Collection and Asset Management System - Title I (DCAMS-T1) 5. F71A Debt Collection and Asset Management System - Generic Debt (DCAMS-GD) 6. A21 Loan Accounting System (LAS) -HUD CFO delinquent borrower reporting C. CAIVRS/F57 provides data to the following Single Family systems 1. F17 Computerized Homes Underwriting Management System (CHUMS)

projects.name: Debt Collection and Asset Management System - Title I
projects.description: The Debt Collection and Asset Management System is used to monitor and collect defaulted Title I loans for which a claim has been filed by the lender and has been subsequently paid by HUD. The system handles all the collection functions including all the financial activities, billing and dunning, credit bureau reporting, referral of debts to Treasury as required under the Debt Collection Improvement Act (DCIA), 1098 and 1099-C reporting to the IRS, processing collection files from a number of sources.

projects.name: Debt Collection and Asset Management System - Generic Debt
projects.description: The Debt Collection and Asset Management System - Generic Debt is used to monitor and collect delinquent FHA receivables. The system handles all the collection functions including all the financial activities, billing and dunning, credit bureau reporting, referral of debts to Treasury as required under the Debt Collection Improvement Act (DCIA), 1098 and 1099-C reporting to the IRS, processing collection files from a number of sources.

projects.name: Title I Insurance and Claims
projects.description: The Title I Insurance and Claims System (TIIS) provides operational and management support for the xecution of the Title I Property Improvement, including FHA PowerSaver, and Manufactured Home Loan programs. It provides online inquiry and updating to support day-to-day operations. This includes loan inventory, maintenance, billing, premium collection and reconcilement, claim processing, and Title I Reserves, maintenance and accounting.

projects.name: Tenant Rental Assistance Certification System
projects.description: TRACS is a mainframe systemimplemented for receiving and maintaining Tenant Certification Data. TRACS was enhanced to become the official repository for Multifamily Housingâ€™s Rental Assistance Project Based Contracts. TRACS was also enhanced to receive, monitor, and process Voucher Payments. TRACS continues to be enhanced to provide additional support to the Office of Multifamily Housing to monitor and report Multifamily Rental Assistance Project Based activities. TRACS consists of four (4) primary business systems â€“ the Contract Business System, Tenant Business System, the Voucher/Payment Business System, and the file transfer system, the integrated Multifamily Access Exchange System (iMax). Within these four (4) business systems, eight (8) significant subsystems comprise and provide specialized functionality: â€¢Integrated Contracts (iCon) is a browser-based (J2EE) subsystem that supports the MFH rental assistance repository. â€¢Automated Renewal and Amendment Management Subsystem (ARAMS) is a browser-based subsystem that supports HUD funding functions for contract renewals and amendments. â€¢Tenant Address Subsystem maintains the repository of tenant unit and mailing addresses to support those HUD applications requiring the ability to locate the tenantâ€™s physical location or mail a document to their mailing address. This repository is currently a resource for the Real Estate Assessment Center (REAC) applications. â€¢Tenant On-Line System provides HUD staff with extensive query capability against the Tenant database together with the ability to order over a dozen different management reports on contracts or projects. â€¢Tenant Internet/Intranet Query provides HUD staff and owners, agents, and CAs (Internet) with secure access to current tenant data for those contracts and projects they are authorized to review. â€¢Voucher Internet/Intranet Query provides HUD staff and owners, agents, and CAs with a secure access to view the most recent 12-months of Voucher activity for those contracts (projects for Rent Supplement and Rental Assistance Program (RAP)) that they are authorized to view. This query enables owners and management agents to check on the status of their own vouchers. â€¢Voucher Internet/Intranet Detail Reports provides HUD staff and owners, agents and CAs downloadable reports similar to the 52670-A Part 1. Triggered by the receipt of a voucher and using the TRACS Tenant database, TRACS will generate the regular payment and the adjustment sections of 52670-A Part 1.

projects.name: Real Estate Assessment Center System
projects.description: This application utility is becoming the one umbrella of all PIH-REAC computer applications, using the latest technologyand allowing easy interface between HUD HQ, its FO's, Public Housing Authority, Multifamily Owners and Agent, Inspectors and Lender.

projects.name: Enterprise Master Data Management Solution
projects.description: The EMDM will be a repository of all master data entities with in HUD. It must have functionality to create, manage, maintain and use data in the data warehouse. These functionalities can be grouped into three main categories/components: â€¢ Data Load: Extract data from source systems, transfer data to staging area, verify data quality and match data from different sources. â€¢ Data warehousing: Correlate, de-normalize and aggregate data. â€¢ Reporting: Allow end users to access and retrieve data in the data warehouse, perform analysis, create reports and use data mining tools.

projects.name: Multifamily Housing Development Coordination Service
projects.description: This project team is the Development Coordination Group (DCG) for all Multifamily Housing using HUD's Internet/Intranet Web-based application architecture (currently Coldfusion/J2EE/Sybase). The project directly supports the database integration and development coordination for the following Multifamily Housing system applications listed by PCAS: Â· 251460--APPS -Active Partners Performance System Â· 251780--ARAMS- Automated Amendment and Renewal System Â· 251850--M2M -Mark-to-Market System Â· 251840--MDDR -Multifamily Default and Delinquency Reporting system Â· 251330--MFCS -Multifamily Claims System Â· 251760--REMS -Real Estate Management System Â· 251780--TRACS -Tenant Rental Assistance Certification System (Intranet/Internet side only)  The highest priority for the project is the integration of data, infrastructure and processes for all current and future systems that utilize Multifamily Housing data. MFHI is not an actual system but rather an application database support utility for Multifamily Housing systems that use and share the MF enterprise database, HEREMS. It is the umbrella of Multifamily Housing systems to share, communicate and interface with HUD IT, Public Housing Authority - REAC, DEC and lenders.

projects.name: Automated Correspondence On-Line Response Network
projects.description: This system tracks correspondence addressed to the Secretary, Under Secretary, all correspondence originating both inside and outside of the Department, action and information memoranda, GAO reports, Reports to Congress, OMB Reports, Freedom of Information Requests, and other special projects. The majority of correspondence are tracked through the Executive Secretariat and the Office of the Secretary. The Cost Worksheet System within ACORN was created to assist in the preparation of the Annual Report to Congress with respect to HUD's Freedom Of Information ACT (FOIA) activities. The CWS processing function allows the creation, modification, or appeal of FOIA correspondence records. It also provides the ability to identify delinquent clients.

projects.name: Labor Relations 2000
projects.description: The Labor Relations 2000 (formerly the Labor Relations Automated Program - LRAP) is the streamlined Year2000 compliant system to record, track, update, and generate reports relative to the implementation of Davis Bacon Act in HUD and for HUD projects. LR2000 streamlines operations for enforcing the labor relations standard for HUD projects in the Offices of Labor Relations across the nation. This client server system with a central database will automate the labor relations enforcement process in all field offices and serve as a management information system for the Office of Labor Relations Hud wide. The system provides the following functions: 1) Maintain a comprehensive central database. 2) Provide rapid retrieval of information. 3) Eliminate the need to manually maintain multiple logs. 4) Provides automated ticklers. 5) Provides timely reporting. 6) Provides an automated clearance review for Debarred and Suspended Contractors. 7) Automatically calculates liquidated damages and wage restitutions due employees. 8) Track Maintenance Survey information. 9) Controls all incoming and outgoing correspondence. 10) Produces forms and form letters. 11) Monitors operational reviews. 13) Tracks and monitors complaints, investigations, reports of wage restitutions and appeals. 14) Monitor contractor performance on HUD projects. 15) Disseminates Department of Labor (DOL) wage rate determinations. 16) Provides a multi-level system and database security.

projects.name: moveLINQ System
projects.description: moveLINQ (mLINQS) is the first comprehensive, fully functional application designed expressly to manage government relocation. Long recognized as the most complex facet of E-Gov Travel, every challenge relocation presents is addressed by mLINQs. moveLINQ manages and tracks all aspects of government change of station: â€¢ House Hunting Trips â€¢  En route Travel â€¢  Shipment and Storage of Household Goods â€¢  Temporary Quarters â€¢  Miscellaneous Expense Allowance â€¢  Real Estate â€¢  Withholding Tax and Relocation Income Tax Allowances â€¢ W-2 processing â€¢ Relocation Cost Reporting moveLINQ features include: â€¢ Compliance with and enforcement of the government relocation policies outlined in the Federal Travel Regulations Chapter 302 and Department of State Standardized Regulations â€¢ Storing pertinent Employee data including address, salary, dependent and tax information â€¢  Creating, tracking and storing relocation expense documents - Authorizations, Vouchers, Amendments, and RITA Vouchers â€¢  Summarizing expenses at a Relocation level, combining all authorizations and vouchers associated with a single relocation in a single summary view â€¢  Current Per Diem, Mileage, Payroll and Tax Rates pertinent to government relocation and provides for automated updates â€¢  Agency fiscal data such as accounting codes, TA numbers, costs, allowable expenses, expense categories, and payment methods â€¢ Support for 3rd Party costs by maintaining a comprehensive vendor and vendor type table â€¢  Storing, tracking and managing advances Accurately calculating Withholding Tax Allowance and Relocation Income Tax Allowance based on government tax tables Providing accurate tax details including Federal and State Withholding, FICA, and HIT â€¢  A Standard Data Output compliant with standards provided by the General Services â€¢ Administration for interfaces to accounting and other agency systems â€¢  Robust relocation reports â€¢  Comprehensive online documentation to support end users use of the application â€¢  Printable authorization and voucher forms

projects.name: Correspondence Management System
projects.description: This system is designed to track and manage correspondence using a paperless (image enabled) workflow technology. The system will also provide management reports and query capability. Ideally it will be used not just by those managing the correspondence process but down all the way to the response writers. This system will be developed using the Eastman OPEN/Image OPEN/workflow software. It uses the standard Eastman desktop, various 'C' user exits, an MS SQL Server supporting database, and Crystal Reports for reporting. The system was intended to be first of a series of prototypes which would result in a system used nationwide, down to the writer level, for all types of internally and externally initiated correspondence and invitations. Subsequent prototypes and a final system did not occur, however, the prototype proved useful and use continues. The Correspondence Management Subsystem for Congressional and elected official correspondence is used by the Executive Secretariat, CIR and the main correspondence units of 7 major program areas. Incoming correspondence is scanned and those offices needing info copies or alert of high priority (Priority 1) responses have images made available to them via the system. Signed copies of responses are also included in the electronic folder.

projects.name: FHA Subsidiary Ledger
projects.description: The FHA Subsidiary Ledger (FHASL), an implementation of popular commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) PeopleSoft Financials accounting software, is FHAâ€™s official system of record of financial transactions. FHA Subsidiary Ledger is certified by the Financial Systems Integration Office (FSIO), and therefore compliant with Federal Government Financial Accounting and Processing. FHA financial data feeder systems are on various hardware and software platforms. The transactions are rolled-up and summarized in the Financial Transaction Repository (FTR) and then interfaced into the FHA Subsidiary Ledger PeopleSoft General Ledger (GL) module for journal processing. FHA Subsidiary Ledger maintains budgetary, proprietary and memorandum US Standard General Ledger (USSGL) accounts. Financial Statements, internal and external, are generated via COTS PeopleSoft, nVision and Query Reporting from the General Ledger.

projects.name: Grants Interface Management System
projects.description: GIMS runs on a UNIX Sun Solaris platform within HUD. GIMS interfaces with the HUD firewall to communicate directly with the Grants.gov website. Personal computers at HUD headquarters are used to access GIMS through the HUD intranet. The following hardware environment is needed to run GIMS. The development environment will utilize 5 GB of space (database usage, data files, custom application code).

projects.name: HPS - Small Purchase System
projects.description: SPS is HUD's simplified acquisition processing system. SPS automates the high volume, low-dollar value simplified acquisition business process. SPS tracks, records, and prepares documents for small purchases of $100,000 or less. Formal contracts over $100,000 are tracked and recorded in the HUD Procurement System (HPS). Together these two systems provide comprehensive management tools and oversight for the business processes of the Chief Procurement Officer. SPS complies with mandated reporting requirements to the Federal Procurement Data System in accordance with the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act.

projects.name: Hospital Mortgage Insurance Management Information System
projects.description: The system provides the information system capacity HUD needs to avoid claims through careful underwriting and monitoring. It will provide management with early warning of problems so HUD and HHS can intervene before an insured hospital gets into serious financial difficulty. The system greatly enhance HUD's ability to evaluate hospitals where it has so much money and visibility at stake. Specifically, HMIMIS analyzes financial performance of portfolio hospitals, quality of financial feasibility studies, portfolio characteristics, and risks associated with each insured loan. It tracks performance measures such as the timeliness of application and loan modification processing. It will pull together information in one place that is currently scattered among old automated and paper systems, allowing HUD and HHS managers to see the whole picture at a program or specific hospital level.

projects.name: Multifamily Delinquency and Default Reporting System
projects.description: HUD implemented MDDR to provide lenders, who service HUD-FHA insured loans, a mechanism to submit delinquency, default, election to assign, and related loan information to HUD electronically in order to comply with HUD regulation 24 CFR part 200, subpart B. The MDDR system supports the monitoring of FHA defaulted loans and delinquent 202 direct loans. Lenders submit, track, and update FHA defaulted loans through delinquency, default, election to assign, and assigned statuses. Project managers monitor 202 direct loans. MDDR is a web enabled system that: Â· services approximately 350-400 users. Â· collects, tracks and reports on lender/servicer mortgage delinquency, default, and election to assign notifications for FHA loans. Â· allows for the management and oversight of FHA loans during the default status life-cycle. Â· collects, tracks, and reports on 202 direct loans.

projects.name: HUDweb (HUD@work)
projects.description: The purpose of this initiative is to maintain and improve HUD's web sites (hud.gov and HUDweb). The initiative supports all of the department's management objectives, the Deputy Secretary's directive to implement the recommendations of the WEb Management Task Force; and various laws--including Paperwork elimination Act and the Americans with Disabilities A This initiative calls for continuing the efforts to improve both content and capabilities of HUD's web sites, so that they continue to provide citizens, HUD's business partners, and HUD employees with the most useful and effective information, tools, and services. Additional Software not listed in the Programming and Communications Environment Section: - RealPlayer 8

projects.name: Resident Assessment Sub-System
projects.description: RASS supports the Resident Service and Satisfaction Survey which is the fourth indicator in HUD's public housing assessment system (PHAS). For the first time,resident satisfaction will be objectively measured and counted in HUD's evaluation of PHAs. This initiative is part of HUD's 2020 Reform to help restore public trust, and implements Executive Order 12862, "Setting Customer Service standards", at HUD. The creation of REAC as a new business center within HUD reflects the Secretary's commitment to addressing material weaknesses identified by the IG in prior reports on PIH. RASS currently supports the pubilc housing Resident Service and Satisfaction survey process. The system has also been modified to support the FHA Multifamily tenant Service and Satisfaction survey process.

projects.name: Customer Assessment Sub-System
projects.description: CASS is the REAC help-desk system. It is a communications channel that allows HUD customers to use REAC performance tools and to share information. This access guarantees equity across our user population and empowers them to improve their futures. CASS is an adaptive platform whose functionality evolves to efficiently address emerging customer needs. It supports all REAC e-business products by ensuring HUD business partners have access to current, accurate, and complete information. REAC's objective is to use CASS to restore public trust and to bridge capability gaps in federal housing programs by enhancing knowledge management activities. Specifically CASS will target elimination of the following weaknessess: * Invalid or inappropriate performance measures, * Single loop product delivery learning systems, and * Process oriented service systems.

projects.name: Financial Assessment Sub-System-FHA
projects.description: The Real Estate Assessment Center (REAC) FASS-FHA system is a key component of HUD's overall portfolio assessment system since HUD manages 30,000 multifamily housing projects representing $40B of mortgage insurance or loan risk and $12B of annual project-based subsidies. The FASS-FHA system collects annual project financial statement information to assess the project's financial performance and compliance and has accepted and assessed over 78,000 electronic submissions of Annual Financial Statement (AFS) data since October of 1998. It identifies financial risks and compliance deficiencies in need of loss mitigation or enforcement actions by the Office of Housing (Housing) or Enforcement Center (EC). The financial data collected by REAC, Housing and EC as well as other HUD program offices, is used to assess multifamily properties for non-compliance and poor performance. The automated assessments and on-line analysis provided by FASS-FHA assists HUD's limited program monitoring and enforcement staff in prioritizing review of properties. The FASS-FHA system is responsible for eliminating time consuming and costly clearinghouse collection and manual assessment efforts previously performed by HUD contractors and field staff. FASS-FHA provides REAC with: Â· the ability to accept electronic submissions of AFS data for the multifamily portfolio; Â· automated compliance checks, financial performance assessments, and referral recommendations that allow prioritization of reviews; Â· Inbox and Selection Criteria screens that allows REAC analysts and Multifamily Housing (MFH) Project Managers to view AFS data and assessment results for each AFS data submission and facilitates workload management; Â· the ability for owners or their authorized agents to electronically submit administrative requests associated with the AFS data submission process (extensions, waivers, resubmission requests); Â· the ability to process administrative requests on-line and communicate the decision via an industry Status Box; the ability to automatically determine and track properties for which an AFS data submission is overdue; Â· the ability for REAC managers to QA referrals; Â· the ability to refer the IPA for submissions to QASS.

projects.name: Financial Assessment Sub-System Public Housing Agency
projects.description: In June 1997, HUD announced it was embarking the most far-reaching and ambitious reform initiatives in its history. The new HUD 2020 Management Reform Plan included, among other changes, the establishment of the Public and Indian Housing - Real Estate Assessment Center (PIH-REAC). PIH-REAC is an information-intensive HUD operation that evaluates the performance of field entities managing or owning housing in which the Department has either a financial interest or a statutory monitoring obligation. (Note that the majority of these properties are public housing or multifamily properties.) As part of this Enterprise-Wide Strategic Plan, HUD made three decisions that require most significant transformations of the FASS-PH program that have ever been undertaken. One decision is that it will take a quantum leap in its effort to improve the granularity of its monitoring of local Public Housing Authorities (PHAs). A second is that it will start using, and eventually migrate all of its stored data to Oracle. Third, it will shift to using an open source, Java-based programming language, often called J2EE (completed). The decision has been made to create a more transparent reporting system that will provide a greater level of granularities at the property level. The objective is to collect expenses and revenues from a Project Based Management (PBM) perspective â€“ specifically by dividing the properties managed by individual Public Housing Agencies/Authorities (PHAs) into more manageable sized groupings called Asset Management Projects (AMPs). To help implement this, HUD will also encourage the creation of a Central Office Cost Center (COCC) for each PHA with more than one AMP. These COCCs (or private management companies) will serve as the vehicle through which a PHA can provide administrative and maintenance services to its AMPs, and through which it can keep an accounting of the expenditures for those services (conversion to AMP completed). As a result of these changes, the FASS-PH software will have to be changed to capture, evaluate and grade the new financial information being submitted by the PHAs. This will require a number of new financial data input screens for PHAs, evaluation screens for Real Estate Assessment Center (REAC) Staff, and the back-end processes that drive these and other submission-scoring operations. Additional software tools not listed in the Programming and Communications Environment Section: * MS Visual Studio 2006

projects.name: Lender Assessment Sub-System
projects.description: The Lender Assessment SubSystem (LASS) was initially developed by the Real Estate Assessment Center (REAC). REAC developed the Lender Assessment Subsystem (LASS) to automate and improve the process of capturing annual, audited financial and compliance data for HUD approved Non-supervised mortgagees and loan correspondents. The system currently resides under the purview of HUDâ€™s Single Family Housing Office of Lender Activities. The LASS System is a web-based application that collects and assesses financial data from approximately 7,000 Non-supervised Loan Correspondents and Mortgagees. LASS provides FHA personnel with real-time access to risk management information associated with lender and issuer activities related to over $700 billion of mortgage insurance in-force and mortgage-backed securities. The LASS system provides HUD with a comprehensive tool to identify and measure potential risk factors posed by lenders to the insured portfolio. LASS assists in addressing the material weakness identified in FHAâ€™s FY2000 audited financial statement which states that â€œFHA must continue to place more emphasis on early warning and loss prevention for single family insured mortgages. It also addresses concerns expressed in an Inspector General (IG) report, which cited FHA for being lax on lender reviews. The LASS system complies with the requirements of OMB Circulars A-123, â€œInternal Control Systemsâ€ and A-127, â€œFinancial Management Systems.â€ Additionally, it addresses the 24 CFR Part 5, UFRS, Subpart H, Section 5.801 (b) which was amended to state: â€œEntities (or individuals) to which this subpart is applicable must provide to HUD, on an annual basis, such financial information as required by HUD.â€

projects.name: Management Assessment Sub-System REAC
projects.description: MASS tracks Public Housing Authority (PHA) management operations indicator information as mandated by the Public Housing assessment System (PHAS) Final Rule, published September 1, 1998, and effective for PHAs with fiscal year ending September 30, 1999, and later. MASS centralizes the public housing management risk analysis process, relieves Field Offices of the burdens associated with data entry and analysis, and provides REAC with a comprehensive tool to monitor, review, score and track a PHA?s management performance. PHAs will submit their management indicator information directly into MASS where the data will be automatically scored. This allows HUD to target risks while making the best use of the Department?s limited resources. Management assessment is the third of four indicators to be assessed under the PHAS rule issued to reflect the operations of the REAC and includes: Â· Vacant unit turnaround time Â· Capital Fund Â· Work Orders Â· Annual inspection of dwelling units and systems Â· Security Â· Economic self-sufficiency MASS is currently broken up into 6 implementation releases. Releases 1, 2, 3 and 4 have been previously implemented into production. Releases 5 and 6 carry all SDM phases of the MASS initiative into FY 2002. Release 5 was developed to support the REAC invalidation process, improve the evaluative nature of the current management indicators, enhance navigation and improve the current pages with updated and/or new information. Release 6 has focused on the development of new management reporting functions and the improvement of existing reporting functions. Additional Software Tools not listed in Programming and Software Environment: * MS Visual Studio 2006

projects.name: iNtegrated Assessment Sub-System
projects.description: System and infrastructure for gathering all the REAC PHA assessment results,analyzing the data and reporting results to the REACs business partners. Supports the PHAS rule. NASS will be the REACs main communication and reporting tool for PHAs and those in HUD charged with regulating and/or monitoring PHAs. System links financial, management, physical and resident assessment results and provides PHAS scores and analyses. Analyses include risk analysis, prescriptive advice, peer comparison, fraud analysis, and trend analysis. These analyses can be used by HUD to provide further insight into PHAs overall performance. Additional Software tools that are not listed in the Programming and Communications Environment Section: â€¢ MS Visual Studio 2006

projects.name: Web Access Security System
projects.description: The purpose of the WEB Access Security System (WASS) is to provide a common framework for administering application-level security for HUD systems. HUD's internal staff and external trusted business partners require access to many of HUD's proprietary systems. In order to provide secured, controlled access to these systems, the Secure Systems and Secure Connection are components of REAC's WEB Access Security System (WASS). New systems developed for HUD that require secure access to proprietary HUD information must use the WASS security framework. WASS supports a growing number of systems and users. WASS will continually seek to make improvements to its existing system and communication processes.

projects.name: Quality Assessment Sub-System
projects.description: Implementation of quality assessment software and infrastructure. Supports HUD 2020 reform to support cross cutting assessments of independent public accountants, single family appraisers, public housing agencies and multi-family owners and agents and identifies high performers for deregulation. Supports the PHAS rule by ensuring the quality of the rating and monitoring public housing projects. Supports planned multi-family assessment rule and addressees multi-family monitoring material weakness by quality reviews. Scope: Implementation of QA processes for Financial and physical Inspection processes, communication/reporting, referrals, tracking. Additional software tools not listed in the Programming and Software Environment Section: * MS Visual Studio 2006

projects.name: Physical Assessment Sub-System-PIH/REAC
projects.description: Implementation of physical assessment software and infrastructure. Supports HUD 2020 reform to support cross cutting assessments of public housing and multi-family housing and identifies high performers for deregulation. Supports the PHAS rule by rating and monitoring public housing projects. Supports the Lead-Based Paint Inspection rule. Supports planned multi-family assessment rule and addresses multi-family monitoring material weakness. Real Estate Assessment Center's (REAC) mission is to monitor and assess the condition of properties and performance of the entities managing or owning housing in which the Department has a financial interest or statutory obligation to monitor. The stated mission is the focal point of HUD 2020 reform efforts. The Office of Inspector General (OIG) reports that $65.6 billion of HUD's reported net position comprises funds appropriated to HUD to provide housing and community development assistance. These funds are at risk as identified in the material weaknesses and reportable conditions outlined in the 1998 OIG audit. The REAC is responsible for amending and, where practicable, correcting the following material weaknesses and reportable conditions related to the need to: Â·Ensure that subsidies are based upon the correct tenant income; Improve monitoring of multifamily projects; Continue to place more emphasis on early warning and loss prevention for FHA insured mortgages; Â·Improve FHA's information technology systems to support their business process more effectively; Â·Improve HUD's management control programs; Refine performance measures to effectively implement results management; Improve controls over project-based subsidy payments; and Â·Enhance the design and operation of FHA's information systems' general and application controls. Scope: communication/Reporting, System enhancements (multiple hits, partial inspections), trend analysis, integration.

projects.name: Configuration Management for Unisys
projects.description: CMPLUS provides a development environment that includes software configuration management, problem tracking, application building and installation. CMPLUS will: Â· Allow identification of all components that comprise a particular change or release Â· Provide Application Baseline Management Â· Provide Application Transfer Â· Enable role based security Â· Guarantee source to object integrity Â· Manage software versions throughout the development life cycle Â· Provide audit facilities and reporting tools Â· Provide automated build facilities Â· Provide the ability to identify and revert to a previous baseline Â· Provide Source Control Â· Support and manage parallel (concurrent) development.

projects.name: PIH Inventory Management System
projects.description: IMS is based on Microsoft Windows DNA, with Active Server Pages as a front end. It uses XSL, XML and COM objects in the middle tier, with SQL Server 2000 as a back end. The Form 50058 submission module is written in J2EE. It has over 3000 configuration items and 3.5 million lines of code. Via Internet and Intranet, it supports more than 22,000 users in HQ, FOs, and over 4000 PHAs. IMS is the system that allows HUD to show who we are assisting, in order to meet Congressional and OMB targets. It provides significant data to EIV (P181) and most REAC systems. Additional Software tools that are not listed in the Programming and Software Environment Section: â€¢ MS Visual Studio 2006

projects.name: Security Control and Tracking System
projects.description: Used to maintain records of employees who have had security investigations.

projects.name: Service Ticket Action Resolution System
projects.description: To create and track IT information and assistance requests to resolution. If calls are resolved by initial contact, call ticket is opened and closed by that agent. If additional work is required by OIT in order to resolve the issue, a "problem ticket" is opened and reassigned to second level technician. Provides detailed IT management reports on systems support.

projects.name: Quality Management Review Program
projects.description: The QMR system is a Lotus Notes Domino/Internet system that provides a streamlined electronic process for administering the Quality Management Review Program reviewer team nominations, questionnaires, plans, interview schedules and findings. The system is administered by ODOC but used by all members of the review teams. The Nomination process involves generation of emails to possible review team participants with a link to a form they complete and submit to the QMR Nominations database. .

projects.name: Audit Resolution and Corrective Action Tracking System
projects.description: ARCATS was migrated from its legacy Lotus Notes platform to the AINS eCase cloud platform as a service (PaaS) on July 21, 2015. ARCATS relies on HUDâ€™s Microsoft Active Directory based general support system (GSS) computer network , eCase role-based permissions assignments security software, and configuration management to protect the system and information.

projects.name: Performance Accountability and Communication System (PACS/EPACS)
projects.description: This will capture rating factors for HUD Managers. It is also used for planning the duties of the employees.

projects.name: Neighborhood Networks
projects.description: Neighborhood Networks is a community-based program created by HUD in 1995. Through innovative private/public partnerships, Neighborhood Networks facilitates the establishment and maintenance of multi-service community technology centers (CTCs) that bring digital opportunity and life-long learning to low-and moderate-income residents living in Multifamily assisted and/or insured housing. With more than 1,300 Neighborhood Networks centers currently operating in HUD multifamily housing properties throughout all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands, Neighborhood Networks continues to grow. Hundreds of additional CTCs operate under HOPE VI, and other Public and Indian Housing programs. The Neighborhood Networks program is assisted in its implementation through approximately 77 HUD Neighborhood Networks Coordinators. Coordinators are located in most of the HUD field offices around the country.

projects.name: Prepared by Client Tracking Database
